title: BitClock: Modern Android Time Management
subtitle: A Feature-Rich Alarm & Utility Application
speaker_notes: Welcome to the presentation of BitClock. This project is a modern Android application designed to handle all your time management needs, from alarms to sleep tracking.

title: Table of Contents
speaker_notes: Here is our agenda. We will start with the objectives and motivation, move through the technical implementation details like architecture and frontend choices, and finish with our achievements.

title: Introduction & Objectives
bullets: **Goal**: Create a reliable, user-friendly clock application.
**Key Features**: Alarm, Stopwatch, Timer, and Sleep Schedule.
**Tech Stack**: Native Android (Java), MVVM, Room Database.
**Deliverable**: A fully functional APK with offline persistence.
speaker_notes: BitClock aims to replace standard clock apps with a more integrated experience. Our primary objective was to build a robust system using modern Android architecture components like MVVM and Room.

title: Motivation & Contribution
bullets: **Problem**: Many clock apps are cluttered or lack sleep tracking.
**Solution**: BitClock integrates sleep scheduling with standard alarms.
**Novelty**: Clean Material 3 Design with intuitive sleep management.
**Contribution**: Open-source reference for MVVM + Hilt implementation.
speaker_notes: We identified that users often need multiple apps for alarms and sleep tracking. BitClock solves this by combining them. It also serves as a clean architectural reference for other developers.

title: Structured Approach: SDLC
speaker_notes: We followed an Agile approach, allowing us to refine the UI and features iteratively. We started with the basic Alarm feature and progressively added the Stopwatch and Sleep modules.

title: Project Timeline (Gantt)
speaker_notes: Our timeline spanned approximately three months. The first month focused heavily on the frontend, while the second dealt with the complex backend logic of scheduling alarms reliably.

title: Functional & Non-Functional Requirements
bullets: **Functional**: Background Alarm Triggering (even if app closed).
speaker_notes: Critically, the app must wake the device up, requiring specific permissions like USE_FULL_SCREEN_INTENT. Non-functionally, we prioritized low battery consumption and high reliability.

title: System Architecture
bullets: **Data**: Repository Pattern mediating between Room DB and UI.
**UI**: Fragments hosted in a Single Activity (Navigation Component).
speaker_notes: We used the recommended Google architecture. The ViewModel survives configuration changes, and the Repository abstracts the data source, making the app testable and modular.

title: User Flow: Setting an Alarm
bullets: **Step 2**: Selects time and repeat days in Detail Screen.
**Step 4**: Receiver triggers Service -> Ringing Activity appears.
speaker_notes: The primary flow involves the user creating an alarm. This data is saved to the DB and simultaneously registered with the Android System AlarmManager to ensure it rings even if the app is killed.

title: Wireframes & Mockups
bullets: **Evolution**: From rough wireframes to polished Material 3 UI.
speaker_notes: Here you see the evolution from a basic wireframe to the final high-fidelity mockup. We utilize standard Android XML layouts to ensure responsiveness across device sizes.

title: Frontend: Android Native (Java)
bullets: **Why Java?**: Robust, strongly typed, and vast ecosystem.
speaker_notes: We chose native Android development with Java. This provides the best performance and access to system-level APIs like AlarmManager, which cross-platform frameworks might struggle with.

title: Backend: Local Persistence (Room)
bullets: **Why Room?**: Compile-time SQL checks, LiveData support.
speaker_notes: Instead of a remote server, we use a local Room database. This ensures the app works perfectly offline. Room provides safety by verifying our SQL queries at compile time.

title: Data Integration
bullets: **Mechanism**: Dependency Injection injects DAO into Repo.
**Result**: UI updates automatically when DB changes.
speaker_notes: The integration point is the Repository. It wraps the DAO and exposes LiveData. This reactive pattern means our UI never needs to manually 'refresh'; it just reacts to data changes.

title: Conclusion & Future Work
bullets: **Limitations**: No cloud sync; alarms reset if data cleared.
**Future Work**: Smart alarm (wake up in light sleep phase).
speaker_notes: In conclusion, BitClock is a solid foundation for personal time management. Future updates will focus on cloud backup and smarter wake-up algorithms using accelerometer data.
